hints: The measure of the likelihood that an event will occur.
A value between 0 and 1.
Often expressed as a fraction, decimal, or percentage.
A possible result of an experiment or trial.
The result of a single event, like a coin flip.
One specific result in a sample space.
A set of one or more outcomes.
A specific collection of results.
Flipping a head is an example of one.
The set of all possible outcomes of an experiment.
All the possible results.
For a die roll, it is the numbers 1 through 6.
The chance or possibility that something will happen.
Another word for probability.
Describes how probable an event is.
Events that cannot occur at the same time.
Flipping heads and tails on one flip are an example of these.
Their intersection is an empty set.
The outcome of one event does not affect another.
Flipping a coin and rolling a die are examples.
The probability of A and B is P(A) * P(B).
The outcome of one event influences another.
Drawing cards from a deck without replacement is an example.
The probability of A and B is P(A) * P(B|A).
Based on reasoning rather than observation.
The number of favorable outcomes divided by the total.
The type of probability used for a fair coin.
Based on the results of an experiment.
Calculated from observed data.
The type of probability often used in science experiments.
Based on personal judgment or opinion.
An expert's opinion on a future event's chance.
A type of probability not based on math or data.
The probability of an event given that another has occurred.
Often written as P(A|B).
Depends on a prior condition.
The probability of two or more events happening together.
Often expressed as P(A and B).
The probability of a two-event intersection.
A function that gives the probabilities of all outcomes.
Shows how likely each possible value is.
The bell curve is an example of one.
A type of continuous probability distribution.
Its graph is a bell-shaped curve.
Symmetrical around its mean.
A discrete probability distribution.
Deals with two possible outcomes, like success or failure.
Used for repeated independent trials.
A discrete probability distribution for a number of events in a time interval.
Used to model rare events.
Often used for counts, like calls to a call center.
A probability distribution where all outcomes are equally likely.
Each result has the same chance of occurring.
A fair die roll is an example.
A fundamental theorem of probability theory.
States that the sampling distribution of the mean will be normal.
It applies to a large sample size.
A theorem that describes the result of performing the same experiment many times.
The more trials, the closer the result gets to the expected value.
Explains why casino games have predictable results over time.
Relates conditional probabilities.
Allows for updating belief based on new evidence.
Named after an 18th-century statistician.
The science of collecting, analyzing, and interpreting data.
A field closely related to probability.
Used to draw conclusions from data.
The average of a set of numbers.
Calculated by summing values and dividing by the count.
A measure of central tendency.
The middle value in a sorted data set.
Half the data points are above it and half are below.
Another measure of central tendency.
The value that appears most frequently in a data set.
There can be one, multiple, or no value for this.
Useful for categorical data.
A measure of how far a set of numbers is spread out.
The square of the standard deviation.
Often represented by sigma squared.
A measure of the amount of variation or dispersion.
The square root of the variance.
A low value means the data points are close to the mean.
A statement or proposition subject to testing.
An educated guess.
Used in statistical tests.
A statistical process for estimating relationships among variables.
Used to predict an outcome based on another variable.
Linear is a common type of this analysis.
A measure of the extent to which two variables are related.
A value between -1 and 1.
A positive value means as one goes up, the other tends to go up.
The entire group that you want to draw conclusions about.
All the items that fit a description.
Can be people, animals, or objects.
A subset of a population.
A small, representative group.
Used to make inferences about the larger group.
A range of values that likely contains the true population parameter.
Often used with a percentage, like 95%.
Gives a range, not a single point estimate.
The probability of obtaining observed results if the null hypothesis is true.
Helps determine statistical significance.
A low value is often considered evidence against the null hypothesis.
A way of selecting items from a collection.
Order does not matter.
Choosing a committee of three people from ten is an example.
A way of selecting items from a collection.
Order does matter.
The arrangement of a batting lineup is an example.
The product of all positive integers up to a given number.
Represented by an exclamation point.
5! equals 120.
A graphical representation of sets.
Uses overlapping circles.
Helps visualize the intersection and union of events.
The graphical representation of a normal distribution.
It is symmetrical.
Highest point is at the mean.
The number of ways of choosing a subset of items.
Appears in the binomial theorem.
Represented as 'n choose k'.
A type of random variable.
Has a finite or countable number of values.
The number of heads in a coin toss is an example.
A type of random variable.
Can take on any value within a given range.
Height or weight are examples.
Without a predictable pattern or bias.
A roll of a die is an example of a this type of event.
Relies on chance.
The weighted average of all possible values.
The long-run average of a random variable.
The sum of each outcome's value multiplied by its probability.
Used to describe a coin or die that is not biased.
Each outcome has an equal probability.
Implies a uniform distribution.
A term for a coin or die that favors certain outcomes.
The outcomes do not have equal probability.
The opposite of fair.
The event that two or more events occur at the same time.
Represented by the symbol 'A ∩ B'.
The area where two circles overlap in a Venn diagram.
The event that at least one of two or more events occurs.
Represented by the symbol 'A ∪ B'.
The total area of two circles in a Venn diagram.
The set of all outcomes that are not in the event.
The event of not getting a head when flipping a coin is this.
A set of events where at least one of them must occur.
The union of all these events makes up the entire sample space.
Getting a head or a tail on a coin toss is an example.
A mathematical construct that provides a formal model of an experiment.
Comprised of a sample space, a set of events, and a probability measure.
A more formal term for the setup of an experiment.
Relating to or involving random variables.
Often used in finance and physics.
A synonym for 'random'.
A measure used to compare the fit of two competing statistical models.
Used in hypothesis testing.
A ratio of the likelihoods of two models.
A discrete probability distribution.
An extension of the binomial distribution with more than two outcomes.
Used when there are multiple categories.
A discrete probability distribution.
Used for the number of trials needed to get the first success.
It has a 'memoryless' property.
A discrete probability distribution.
Used for sampling without replacement.
Deals with drawing from two groups, like red and black balls.
A discrete probability distribution for a single trial.
Has only two possible outcomes, success or failure.
The simplest case of the binomial distribution.
A continuous probability distribution.
Does not have a defined mean or variance.
Used in physics and statistical mechanics.
A continuous probability distribution.
Often used to model the time until a random event occurs.
Like the geometric distribution, it is memoryless.
A continuous probability distribution.
A two-parameter family of continuous distributions.
Includes the exponential and chi-squared distributions.
A continuous probability distribution.
Often used for hypothesis testing, like goodness-of-fit.
Used with categorical data.
A continuous probability distribution.
Similar to a normal distribution but with fatter tails.
Used in place of the normal when the sample size is small.
A continuous probability distribution.
Used to test if two variances are equal.
The ratio of two chi-squared variables.
A graphical representation of data.
Uses bars to show frequency.
Helps visualize the shape of a distribution.
The number of times an event occurs.
How often something happens.
Can be used to calculate empirical probability.
The ratio of an event's occurrences to the total number of outcomes.
A value that can be used to estimate probability.
Calculated as frequency divided by total trials.
A function that describes the relative likelihood of a continuous random variable.
The area under the curve gives the probability.
Often abbreviated as 'PDF'.
Gives the probability that a random variable is less than or equal to a value.
The integral of the probability density function.
Often abbreviated as 'CDF'.
A variable whose value is determined by the outcome of a random experiment.
Can be discrete or continuous.
Its values are numerical outcomes of a random process.
A value that describes a population.
A fixed number, usually unknown.
The mean of a population is an example.
A value that describes a sample.
A value calculated from a data sample.
The mean of a sample is an example.
A rule for calculating an estimate of a parameter.
A sample mean is an estimator of the population mean.
Used in inferential statistics.
The process of drawing conclusions about a population.
Using a sample to make a judgment about a larger group.
This is the goal of inferential statistics.
The process of selecting a subset of a population.
The goal is to get a representative subset.
Can be done randomly or systematically.
A statement of no effect or no difference.
The hypothesis being tested in a statistical test.
Often denoted as 'H sub 0'.
The claim that there is a difference or effect.
The opposite of the null hypothesis.
Often denoted as 'H sub a' or 'H sub 1'.
The threshold for rejecting the null hypothesis.
Commonly set at 0.05 or 5%.
Represented by the Greek letter alpha.
A point on the distribution that defines the rejection region.
Determined by the significance level.
A value used to test a hypothesis.
A measure of how many standard deviations a value is from the mean.
Used to standardize data.
A value of 0 means it is equal to the mean.
The standard deviation of a sampling distribution.
Measures the accuracy of a sample statistic.
Lower value means better accuracy.
The amount of random sampling error in a survey's results.
Determines the size of a confidence interval.
Plus or minus this value is often cited in polls.
The number of independent pieces of information in a data set.
Used in statistical tests like the t-test and chi-squared test.
Often calculated as n-1.
An acronym for 'Analysis of Variance'.
A statistical test for comparing means of three or more groups.
Uses the F-distribution.
A statistical test for categorical data.
Tests for independence between two variables.
Often used to check for goodness of fit.
A statistical test for comparing the means of two groups.
Used when the population standard deviation is unknown.
Uses the student t distribution.
A mathematical object that describes a path consisting of a succession of random steps.
Often used to model stock prices.
Each step is random.
A method that uses repeated random sampling to obtain numerical results.
Used for simulating complex systems.
Named after a well-known casino.
The mathematical study of waiting lines.
Used to model and analyze systems where customers wait for service.
A branch of probability theory.
A method of statistical inference.
Updates the probability of a hypothesis as more evidence becomes available.
Uses Bayes' theorem.
A method of estimating the parameters of a statistical model.
Chooses the parameters that maximize the likelihood function.
A widely used method in statistics.
A function that gives the probability of a discrete random variable being equal to some value.
Often abbreviated as 'PMF'.
Sum of all values is 1.
A diagram used to calculate the probability of multiple events.
Branches represent possible outcomes.
Helps visualize compound events.
A stochastic model describing a sequence of possible events.
The probability of the next state depends only on the current state.
Used in Google's PageRank algorithm.
A property of an estimator.
Having the smallest possible variance.
A desirable property for a statistical method.
A property of an estimator.
Its expected value is equal to the parameter being estimated.
The opposite of a biased estimator.
A property of an estimator.
As the sample size increases, it converges on the true value.
A desirable property for a statistical method.
The probability distribution of a statistic obtained from a large number of samples.
The distribution of sample means or proportions.
Used to make inferences.
A variable that influences both the dependent and independent variables.
Can lead to a spurious association.
A common issue in observational studies.
The repetition of an experiment to confirm results.
A key part of the scientific method.
Helps to build confidence in findings.
A measure of the asymmetry of a probability distribution.
A distribution can be positively or negatively this.
The 'tail' of the distribution points in the direction of this.
A measure of the 'tailedness' of a distribution.
Describes the shape of a distribution's peak and tails.
High value means a sharp peak and heavy tails.
A measure of the joint variability of two random variables.
Shows how two variables change together.
The sign indicates the direction of the relationship.
A standardized measure of the linear relationship between two variables.
Ranges from -1 to +1.
A common type is the Pearson one.
A statistical model that assumes a linear relationship between a dependent and one or more independent variables.
The simplest form of regression analysis.
Creates a straight line to fit the data.
A collection of statistical models to analyze the differences among group means.
It tests whether the means of two or more groups are significantly different from each other.
Its acronym is ANOVA.
The lack of pattern or predictability in a series of events.
A key concept in probability.
Generated by a process that produces outcomes without bias.
A synonym for probability.
Refers to the likelihood of an event.
Often used in casual language.
Having an equal probability.
All outcomes in a sample space are this if they have the same chance of occurring.
A fair die roll has these outcomes.
A single data point.
A single measurement or record.
The result of one experiment or trial.
A square matrix where the diagonal elements are the variances of each variable.
Off-diagonal elements are the covariances between variables.
Used in multivariate statistics.
Another term for the population.
The set of all possible entities or values.
The total group of interest.
A type of probability based on the results of an experiment.
Determined from repeated trials.
The number of successes divided by the number of trials.
Relating to a curve that approaches a line but never touches it.
The normal distribution is an example of this.
A property of some probability distributions.
Involving two random variables.
Describes the relationship between two variables.
Bivariate normal distribution is a common example.
The change in the dependent variable for a one-unit change in the independent variable.
The slope of the regression line.
Also known as beta or slope.
The difference between an observed value and the value predicted by the model.
The error in a regression model.
Used to check the assumptions of a model.
A statistical method for making decisions using data from a study.
Used to test a claim about a population parameter.
Involves the null and alternative hypotheses.
A statistical test for a single population mean.
Used when the population standard deviation is known.
Based on the standard normal distribution.
A measure of linear correlation between two variables.
Its value is between -1 and +1.
A common type of correlation coefficient.
Divides a probability distribution into equal-sized groups.
The median is an example of this.
Percentiles and quartiles are specific types.
A measure used in statistics indicating the value below which a given percentage of observations fall.
The 50th one is the median.
Used for test scores and health measurements.
One of four equal parts of a data set.
The first one is the 25th percentile.
Used to define the interquartile range.
A measure of statistical dispersion.
The difference between the third and first quartiles.
Used to identify outliers.
A graphical display of the five-number summary.
Shows the median, quartiles, and minimum/maximum values.
Also known as a box and whisker plot.
A type of plot or mathematical diagram.
Uses Cartesian coordinates to display values for two variables.
Used to show the relationship between two variables.
A sequence of data points indexed in time.
Used in finance and economics to analyze data over time.
Examples include daily stock prices or temperatures.
Involving a single variable.
Analyzing a single data set.
The opposite of bivariate.
Involving multiple variables.
Analysis of more than two variables at once.
The opposite of univariate and bivariate.
A subset of a population where each member has an equal chance of being selected.
A key to making valid statistical inferences.
Prevents sampling bias.
Dividing a population into subgroups before sampling.
Used to ensure representation from each subgroup.
A type of random sampling.
Dividing a population into groups and then randomly selecting entire groups.
Used when it is impractical to sample from the entire population.
A type of random sampling.
Selecting members from a population at a regular interval.
For example, choosing every 10th person from a list.
A type of random sampling.
Selecting members of a population who are easily accessible.
A type of non-random sampling.
Often leads to sampling bias.
A bias in which a sample is collected in a way that some members of the intended population have a lower or higher sampling probability than others.
Occurs when a sample is not representative of the population.
A common error in research.
A bias that occurs when respondents differ systematically from non-respondents.
A type of sampling bias.
Can happen in surveys.
A bias that occurs when there are errors in the measurement of variables.
Can be caused by faulty equipment or poorly worded questions.
Can lead to inaccurate results.
A bias where only the 'surviving' observations are considered.
An example is judging the performance of mutual funds only by those that still exist.
Can lead to overly optimistic conclusions.
A phenomenon in which a person's physical or mental health appears to improve after taking a placebo.
A type of bias in clinical trials.
A psychological effect.
An experimental procedure in which neither the participants nor the experimenters know who is in the control group.
Used to prevent bias.
A common technique in clinical trials.
A standardized measure of dispersion.
The ratio of the standard deviation to the mean.
Useful for comparing different data sets.
Data that can be measured or counted.
Examples include height, weight, or age.
The opposite of qualitative.
Data that is descriptive or categorical.
Examples include hair color, gender, or favorite color.
The opposite of quantitative.
A type of categorical data.
Data that is in categories without any order.
Hair color is an example.
A type of categorical data.
Data that has a natural order or ranking.
Letter grades (A, B, C) are an example.
A type of numerical data.
Data with ordered intervals of equal size.
Temperature in Celsius or Fahrenheit is an example.
A type of numerical data.
Data with ordered intervals of equal size and a true zero point.
Height or weight are examples.
The branch of statistics that summarizes and describes data.
Includes measures like mean, median, and mode.
The first step in data analysis.
The branch of statistics that uses data to make predictions or inferences.
Includes hypothesis testing and confidence intervals.
Used to generalize from a sample to a population.
A table that shows the area under the standard normal curve.
Used to find the probability associated with a z-score.
Allows you to find the percentile of a value.
A normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.
Used to standardize data.
Also known as the Z-distribution.
A set of five descriptive statistics for a data set.
Includes minimum, first quartile, median, third quartile, and maximum.
Used to create a box plot.
A data point that is far from other data points.
Can be caused by errors or indicate unusual events.
Often identified using the interquartile range.
A function that describes the possible values of a random variable.
Provides the probabilities of those values.
Can be discrete or continuous.
A set of events with no common outcomes.
Another term for mutually exclusive.
The intersection of these events is an empty set.
Used to find the probability of the union of two events.
P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B).
A fundamental rule of probability.
Used to find the probability of the intersection of two events.
P(A and B) = P(A) * P(B|A).
A fundamental rule of probability.
A fundamental theorem relating marginal probabilities to conditional probabilities.
Can be used to calculate a single probability from a number of conditional probabilities.
States that the sum of conditional probabilities is 1.
A school of thought in probability.
Treats probability as a degree of belief.
Uses prior beliefs and updates them with data.
A school of thought in probability.
Assumes all outcomes are equally likely.
The number of favorable outcomes divided by total outcomes.
A school of thought in probability.
Defines probability as the long-run relative frequency of an event.
Relies on repeated trials.
The chance that an event will occur.
A number between 0 and 1.
Symbolically represented as P(E).
The number of times an event occurs in a set of trials divided by the total number of trials.
An estimate of the theoretical probability.
Also known as empirical probability.
Two events that are the only two possible outcomes.
Their probabilities sum to 1.
Example: getting a heads and getting a tails on a coin flip.
An event that has a probability of 0.
An event that cannot happen.
Rolling a 7 on a standard six-sided die is an example.
An event that has a probability of 1.
An event that is guaranteed to happen.
Getting a number from 1 to 6 on a six-sided die is an example.
A distribution for a random variable that can only take on certain values.
The binomial and Poisson distributions are examples.
Usually represented by a bar graph.
A distribution for a random variable that can take on any value within a range.
The normal and exponential distributions are examples.
Represented by a smooth curve.
A distribution that gives the probability of two or more random variables occurring simultaneously.
An extension of a joint probability.
Can be discrete or continuous.
The probability distribution of a single random variable from a joint distribution.
Found by summing or integrating over the other variables.
Gives the probability for one variable alone.
The probability distribution of a random variable given that another random variable has a certain value.
Relates to conditional probability.
The shape changes depending on the condition.
The value at which the probability mass or density function is highest.
The peak of the distribution.
The most likely value.
The value that divides the distribution in half.
The 50th percentile.
Half the probability is to the left, half is to the right.
Values that divide a distribution into equal intervals.
Quartiles and percentiles are examples.
These values mark specific points in the data.
A type of statistical test that makes assumptions about the parameters of the population distribution.
Examples include the t-test and ANOVA.
These tests are more powerful if the assumptions are met.
A type of statistical test that makes no assumptions about the population distribution.
Used when the data is not normally distributed.
Examples include the sign test or Wilcoxon rank sum test.
A formal procedure for making decisions about a population based on sample data.
Involves a null and alternative hypothesis.
Results in a 'reject' or 'fail to reject' conclusion.
A statistical test in which the critical area of a distribution is one-sided.
Used when you are only interested in a change in one direction.
The alternative hypothesis is stated as 'greater than' or 'less than'.
A statistical test in which the critical area of a distribution is two-sided.
Used when you are interested in a change in either direction.
The alternative hypothesis is stated as 'not equal to'.
Rejecting a null hypothesis that is true.
A false positive.
The probability is denoted by alpha.
Failing to reject a null hypothesis that is false.
A false negative.
The probability is denoted by beta.
The probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis.
A value of 1 - beta.
The ability of a test to detect a true effect.
The number of observations in a sample.
A larger value generally leads to more accurate results.
Denoted by 'n'.
A method of selecting a sample from a population.
Each individual has an equal chance of being chosen.
A key to avoiding bias.
A number that describes the entire population.
Usually denoted by a Greek letter, like mu or sigma.
The true value of a characteristic.
A number that describes a sample.
Used to estimate a population parameter.
Usually denoted by a Latin letter, like x-bar or s.
The process of inferring a population parameter from a sample statistic.
Can be a point estimate or an interval estimate.
A core part of inferential statistics.
A single value used to estimate a population parameter.
The sample mean is a this for the population mean.
A single number.
A range of values used to estimate a population parameter.
A confidence interval is an example.
Gives a range, not a single number.
A way to standardize data.
Shows how many standard deviations a value is from the mean.
Also known as a Z-score.
The number of values in a final calculation that can vary.
Often used in statistical tests like the t-test.
Often calculated as n-1.
A statistical test to see if a sample of data comes from a specific distribution.
A common test is the chi-squared one.
Used to evaluate how well a model fits observed data.
A table showing the frequency distribution of two or more categorical variables.
Used in a chi-squared test for independence.
Also known as a cross-tabulation table.
A graph used to determine if a regression model is a good fit.
Plots the residuals against the independent variable.
A random scatter of points is desired.
A statistical test to determine if a data set is normally distributed.
A preliminary test for many parametric tests.
Examples include the Shapiro-Wilk or Kolmogorov-Smirnov test.
A graphical technique for assessing if a data set follows a given distribution.
Plots the observed data against the theoretical quantiles.
A straight line indicates a good fit.
A resampling technique used to estimate the sampling distribution of a statistic.
Involves drawing many samples with replacement from a single original sample.
Used for complex statistics where an analytical solution is difficult.
A resampling technique used to estimate bias and standard error.
Involves repeatedly calculating the statistic by leaving out one or more observations.
An alternative to bootstrapping.
A property of a statistical test.
A measure of how well a statistical test handles deviations from its assumptions.
A test that works well even with non-normal data is this.
A key concept in machine learning and statistics.
The goal is to minimize both bias and variance in a model.
A model with high bias is too simple, a model with high variance is too complex.
A type of probability that treats probability as a degree of belief.
Named after a famous statistician.
Contrasts with the frequentist approach.
A probability that is determined before any data is collected.
An initial belief about a parameter.
A key component of Bayesian inference.
A probability that is determined after new data is collected.
An updated belief about a parameter.
The result of applying Bayes' theorem.
A function of the parameters of a statistical model.
Tells you how well the model fits the data.
Used in maximum likelihood estimation.
The process of using sample data to estimate the values of population parameters.
Can be done using a point estimate or an interval estimate.
A core task in inferential statistics.
A discrete probability distribution.
Models the number of successes in a sequence of draws without replacement.
Used when the population is finite.
A discrete probability distribution.
Models the number of failures before a specified number of successes.
An extension of the geometric distribution.
A mathematical construct that provides a formal model of an experiment.
Consists of three parts: a sample space, an event space, and a probability measure.
A foundational concept in probability theory.
A basic mathematical operation.
The number of outcomes in a sample space.
A fundamental concept in probability.
An arrangement of objects in a specific order.
The order matters.
Used to count the number of ways to arrange a set of objects.
A selection of objects from a set where the order does not matter.
Used to count the number of ways to choose a subset.
A common concept in probability.
An experiment or a process that has more than one possible outcome.
The outcome of the experiment cannot be predicted with certainty.
Flipping a coin or rolling a die are examples.
The long-run average of a random variable.
The weighted average of all possible values.
Another term for expected value.
The difference between a value and the mean, squared.
Used in the calculation of variance and standard deviation.
Always a non-negative value.
A single value that attempts to describe a set of data by identifying the central position.
Includes mean, median, and mode.
A key concept in descriptive statistics.
A value that describes how spread out the data is.
Examples include variance, standard deviation, and range.
Also known as a measure of variability.
A measure of statistical dispersion.
The difference between the third and first quartiles.
Often used to identify outliers.
A standardized way of displaying the distribution of data based on a five-number summary.
Also known as a box and whisker plot.
Visualizes quartiles and potential outliers.
A graph that uses dots to represent values for two different variables.
Used to see if there is a relationship between two variables.
The pattern of the dots indicates the correlation.
A graphical representation of the distribution of numerical data.
Uses bars to show the frequency of data points within intervals.
Looks similar to a bar chart.
A way to represent quantitative data in a graphical format.
Data is organized by place value.
Shows both the shape and the individual data points.
A table that lists items and shows the number of times they occur.
A simple way to summarize data.
Can be used to calculate empirical probability.
A table that shows the proportion of times an event occurs.
Displays the probability of each outcome.
Values in the table sum to 1.
A function that gives the probability that a discrete random variable is exactly equal to some value.
Often abbreviated as PMF.
Used for discrete distributions.
A function that describes the relative likelihood for a continuous random variable.
The area under the curve gives the probability.
Often abbreviated as PDF.
A function that gives the probability that a random variable is less than or equal to a value.
Used for both discrete and continuous variables.
Often abbreviated as CDF.
A variable whose values are numerical outcomes of a random phenomenon.
The value is not fixed.
Can be discrete or continuous.
A random variable with a countable number of possible values.
Examples include the number of heads in coin flips.
Often represented by integers.
A random variable that can take on any value within a given range.
Examples include height, weight, or temperature.
Represented by a continuous line or curve.
An experiment with a fixed number of trials.
Each trial is independent.
There are only two possible outcomes for each trial.
An experiment that counts the number of times an event occurs in a fixed interval of time or space.
The events occur with a known average rate.
Events are independent.
The percentage of all confidence intervals that are expected to contain the true population parameter.
Often set at 95% or 99%.
A key part of a confidence interval.
A range of values that is likely to contain the true value of a population parameter.
The margin of error is added to and subtracted from a point estimate.
A range estimate.
A measure of the precision of an estimate.
Determines the width of a confidence interval.
The plus or minus part of a poll result.
The set of all values for the test statistic for which the null hypothesis is rejected.
Also known as the rejection region.
Its size is determined by the significance level.
A result is this if the p-value is less than the significance level.
Indicates that the observed effect is unlikely to be due to chance.
A key concept in hypothesis testing.
A test statistic used in a z-test.
Measures how many standard errors an observed value is from the null hypothesis value.
Calculated using the sample mean, population mean, and standard error.
A test statistic used in a t-test.
Used when the population standard deviation is unknown.
Follows the student's t-distribution.
A test statistic used in a chi-squared test.
Measures the difference between observed and expected frequencies.
Follows the chi-squared distribution.
A mathematical description of a random phenomenon.
Consists of a sample space and a way of assigning probabilities.
A simplified representation of a real-world process.
The set of all possible outcomes of an experiment.
For a coin flip, it is {heads, tails}.
The foundation of a probability model.
A collection of all possible events.
A subset of the sample space.
The events can be simple or compound.
A function that assigns a probability to each event in the event space.
Follows three axioms.
A fundamental component of a probability space.
The three basic rules that govern probability.
State that probability is non-negative, the probability of the sample space is 1, and the probability of disjoint events is additive.
Also known as the Kolmogorov axioms.
Events that cannot happen at the same time.
Their intersection is an empty set.
Flipping heads and tails on a single flip are an example.
A set of events where at least one of them must occur.
The union of all these events is the entire sample space.
Example: getting a heads or a tails on a coin toss.
Events for which the outcome of one does not affect the outcome of the other.
The probability of both occurring is the product of their individual probabilities.
Flipping a coin and rolling a die are examples.
Events for which the outcome of one event influences the outcome of the other.
The probability of both occurring is P(A) times P(B given A).
Drawing cards from a deck without replacement is an example.
A graphical tool used to calculate the number of outcomes of a probability experiment.
Branches represent possible outcomes.
A visual representation of all possible outcomes.
A diagram that shows all possible logical relations between a finite collection of different sets.
Uses overlapping circles.
Helps visualize the union and intersection of events.
A rule that relates the probability of an event to its conditional probabilities.
Allows you to find the probability of a single event from a set of disjoint events.
A foundational concept in probability.
A formula used to update the probability of a hypothesis after new evidence is obtained.
Relates prior and posterior probabilities.
A core concept in Bayesian statistics.
The probability of an event occurring given that another event has already occurred.
Symbolically, P(A|B).
The probability of A, given B.
The probability of two or more events occurring at the same time.
Symbolically, P(A ∩ B).
The probability of the intersection of two events.
The probability of a single event occurring.
Calculated by summing the joint probabilities over all other variables.
The probability of an event without reference to other events.
A function that gives the probability of a discrete random variable being equal to some value.
Often abbreviated as PMF.
Used for discrete distributions.
A function that describes the relative likelihood of a continuous random variable.
The area under the curve gives the probability.
Often abbreviated as PDF.
The weighted average of all possible values of a random variable.
The long-run average of a random process.
Also known as expectation.
A measure of how far a set of numbers is spread out from their average.
The square of the standard deviation.
A key measure of dispersion.
A measure of the amount of variation or dispersion of a set of values.
The square root of the variance.
A low value indicates that the values tend to be close to the mean.
A measure of the joint variability of two random variables.
A positive value means that the variables tend to move in the same direction.
An unstandardized version of correlation.
A measure of the linear relationship between two variables.
Ranges from -1 to 1.
A value of 0 means no linear relationship.
A statistical process for estimating the relationships among variables.
Used to predict the value of one variable based on another.
Linear and logistic are common types.
The branch of statistics that uses sample data to make inferences about a population.
Includes hypothesis testing and confidence intervals.
The opposite of descriptive statistics.
The branch of statistics that summarizes and describes the main features of a collection of data.
Includes measures like mean, median, and mode.
The first step in data analysis.
A value that describes a characteristic of an entire population.
Usually a fixed number.
The population mean is an example.
A value that describes a characteristic of a sample.
Used to estimate a population parameter.
The sample mean is an example.
The probability distribution of a statistic obtained from a large number of samples.
The distribution of sample means.
A key concept in inferential statistics.
A theorem that states that the sampling distribution of the mean will be approximately normal.
It holds true for large sample sizes.
A foundational theorem in statistics.
A theorem that describes the result of performing the same experiment many times.
The average of the results obtained from a large number of trials should be close to the expected value.
Explains why gambling houses are profitable.
A collection of random variables indexed by time or space.
Used to model phenomena that evolve randomly over time.
Examples include stock prices or weather patterns.
A stochastic process that satisfies the Markov property.
The future state depends only on the current state.
A memoryless process.
The branch of mathematics concerned with probability.
The theoretical foundation for statistics.
Deals with the analysis of random phenomena.
The branch of mathematics that deals with counting, arrangement, and combination.
A key tool for solving probability problems.
Includes permutations and combinations.
The branch of mathematics that studies sets.
Sets are collections of objects.
Used to define events and sample spaces in probability.
The property of a data set that follows a normal distribution.
Many statistical tests require this assumption.
Can be tested with a probability plot.
A measure of the asymmetry of a probability distribution.
A distribution can be positively or negatively skewed.
The 'tail' of the distribution points in the direction of the skew.
A measure of the 'tailedness' of a distribution.
Describes the shape of a distribution's peak and tails.
A high value means a sharp peak and heavy tails.
A statistical method for modeling the relationship between two variables.
The goal is to find the best-fitting straight line.
Used for prediction and forecasting.
The difference between an observed value and the predicted value in a regression model.
Also known as the error.
Used to check the model's assumptions.
A value that represents the change in the dependent variable for a one-unit change in the independent variable.
The slope of the regression line.
The 'beta' in a regression equation.
A standardized measure of the linear relationship between two variables.
Ranges from -1 to 1.
The Pearson one is a common example.
A statistical method for making decisions based on data.
Involves a null and an alternative hypothesis.
Used to test a claim about a population.
The probability of obtaining observed data if the null hypothesis is true.
Used to determine statistical significance.
A low value leads to the rejection of the null hypothesis.
The threshold for rejecting the null hypothesis.
Commonly set at 0.05.
Also known as alpha.
A value on a distribution that marks the boundary of a rejection region.
Determined by the significance level.
Used in hypothesis testing.
A measure of how many standard deviations an observation is from the mean.
Used to standardize data from a normal distribution.
A value of 0 means the observation is equal to the mean.
A standardized score used with the t-distribution.
Used in t-tests.
Similar to a z-score but used with smaller sample sizes.
A statistical test used to determine if there is a significant association between two categorical variables.
Used to test for goodness of fit or independence.
A non-parametric test.
A statistical test used to compare the means of two groups.
Used when the population standard deviation is unknown.
A common parametric test.
A statistical test used to compare the means of three or more groups.
Acronym for Analysis of Variance.
An extension of the t-test.
A discrete probability distribution.
Describes the number of successes in a sequence of n independent trials.
Each trial has only two outcomes.
A continuous probability distribution.
Its graph is a symmetric, bell-shaped curve.
The most common distribution in statistics.
A discrete probability distribution.
Describes the number of events that occur in a fixed interval of time or space.
Used for counting rare events.
A discrete probability distribution.
Describes the number of trials needed to get the first success.
A key concept in probability theory.
A continuous probability distribution.
Describes the time between events in a Poisson process.
A key concept in reliability theory.
A probability distribution where all outcomes are equally likely.
The probability density function is a constant.
A fair die roll follows this distribution.
A function that gives the probabilities of all possible values of a random variable.
The set of all possible outcomes and their associated probabilities.
The foundation of statistical inference.
The process of selecting a subset of a population.
A key step in statistical analysis.
Can be random or non-random.
The entire group of individuals or objects that you want to study.
The group you are trying to make a conclusion about.
A key concept in statistics.
A subset of a population.
Used to make inferences about the larger group.
A key concept in inferential statistics.
